PAGE.TITLE: The moment generating function
PAGE.DESCRIPTION:
The moment generating function, $M_X(t)$, of a random variable, $X$, is defined as:
$$
M_X(t) = \mathbb{E}(e^{tX})
$$
You can calculate the $n$th moment of a random variable, $\mathbb{E}(X^n)$ from the moment
generating function as follows:
$$
\mathbb{E}(X^n) = \frac{\textrm{d}^n M_X(0)}{\textrm{d}t^n}
$$
In other words the value of the $n$th derivative of the moment generating function at $t=0$ is
equal to the $n$th moment.

UL.LI: You should be able to explain what is meant by the $n$th moment of a random variable and the $n$th central moment.
You should be able to write an expression for the moment generating function of both continuous and discrete random variables.
You should be able to explain how to calculate the $n$th moment of a random variable from the moment generating function.
You should be able to derive the moment generating functions for Binomial and Poisson random variables.
